column2: Emission Factors for Rail, Bus and Car Travel

column3: Definition of short haul: less than
Definition of medium haul: less than
Definition of long haul: more than

1) Air travel definitions and factors are from the GHG Protocol Mobile Combustion Tool.  The emissions factors for short and long haul flights are originally from UK DEFRA.  The emissions factor for medium haul flights was derived, using an assumed distance of 1600 km and the following formulae.
X+500y =.15*500 for short haul
X+5000y=.11*5000 for long haul
Based on Emission Factors provided by UK DEFRA (Table 9, Annexes to Guidelines for Company Reporting on Greenhouse Gas Emissions, updated July 2005) for short haul and long haul flights
http://www.defra.gov.uk/environment/business/envrp/gas/
Note: these emissions factors are based on data from the UK.
Source: U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA): Voluntary Reporting of Greenhouse Gases Program, Emission Coefficients, http://www.eia.doe.gov/oiaf/1605/factors.html.
Note: Jet kerosene is used by jet engines only.  Aviation gasoline is used in piston powered airplanes.  Jet kerosene is more common.

column6: To go from lbs to kg, multiply by

column3: 1. Source: Railtrack http://www.railtrack.co.uk/our_business/environment/benefits_of_rail/index.cfm gives annual passenger-miles and tonnes of CO2.

2.  To obtain this number, the following were multiplied:                                                                                         ((115.717 million gallons diesel [TEDB]* 10.15 kg CO2/gallon [EIA] + (817.208 million kwh [TEDB] * 1.34 lbs CO2/ kwh [EIA] * 0.4536 kg/lb [conversion] )/ 5314 million revenue passenger miles [TEDB]
Source: 
- Transportation Energy Data Book (TEDB): Edition 24, 2004. Table 2.11 and A.16.
http://www-cta.ornl.gov/data.
- U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA): Voluntary Reporting of Greenhouse Gases Program, Emission Coefficients, http://www.eia.doe.gov/oiaf/1605/factors.html.                                                                                   - U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA): Updated State-level Greenhouse Gas Emission Coefficients for Electricity Generation 1998-2000, April 2002, http://tonto.eia.doe.gov/FTPROOT/environment/e-supdoc-u.pdf.

3. To obtain this number, the following were multiplied:
4193 million kWh[TEDB]/ 15095 million psgr-miles [TEDB] * 1.34 lbsCO2/kwh [EIA] * 0.4536 kgCO2/lbsCO2 [conversion]
Sources: 
- Transportation Energy Data Book (TEDB): Edition 24, 2004, Table 2.11 and Table A.15.                                    http://www-cta.ornl.gov/data.
- U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA): Updated State-level Greenhouse Gas Emission Coefficients for Electricity Generation 1998-2000, April 2002, http://tonto.eia.doe.gov/FTPROOT/environment/e-supdoc-u.pdf.
Note: Transit rail is defined as light rail and heavy rail. For definitions, please see 
http://www.apta.com/research/stats/rail/definitions.cfm.

4. To obtain this number, the following were multiplied:                                                                                          ((72.847 million gallons diesel [TEDB]* 10.15 kg CO2/gallon [EIA] + (1334 million kwh [TEDB] * 1.34 lbs CO2/ kwh [EIA] * 0.4536 kg/lb [conversion] )/ 9504 million revenue passenger miles [TEDB]
Source: 
TEDB = Transportation Energy Data Book: Edition 24, 2004. Table 2.11 and A.14.
http://www-cta.ornl.gov/data.
- Energy Information Administration (EIA): Voluntary Reporting of Greenhouse Gases Program, Emission Coefficients, http://www.eia.doe.gov/oiaf/1605/factors.html.                                                                                   - Energy Information Administration (EIA): Updated State-level Greenhouse Gas Emission Coefficients for Electricity Generation 1998-2000, April 2002, http://tonto.eia.doe.gov/FTPROOT/environment/e-supdoc-u.pdf.
Note: Commuter rail is defined by the American Public Transportation Association (APTA) at http://www.apta.com/research/stats/rail/definitions.cfm. A list of agencies in the U.S. that are considered commuter rail can be found at http://www.apta.com/research/stats/rail/crservuse.cfm.

5. Source: Canada’s Climate Change Voluntary Challenge and Registry Inc. (VCR Inc.), 2002. An Action Plan for Reducing Greenhouse Gas Emissions. P 12. www.vcr-mvr.ca. Please note that units are in CO2-eq.

Source for diesel: Bureau of Transportation, National Transportation Statistics for 2000.
Source for CNG: Multiplies diesel (urban) emissions per unit by 56/73.9, the ratio of CO2 emissions per terajoule, natural gas to diesel. Emission factors are based on lower heating values. They are sourced from Revised IPCC, 1996, Vol. 2, Table 1-2.
Source: Energy Information Administration (EIA): Voluntary Reporting of Greenhouse Gases Program, Emission Coefficients, http://www.eia.doe.gov/oiaf/1605/factors.html.
